titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Yamato Ichihashi Papers SC0071 SC0071
titlestmt.author: Processed by Special Collections staff; machine-readable finding aid created by Patricia White

publicationstmt.publisher: Department of Special Collections and University Archives

note.p: This encoded finding aid is compliant with Stanford EAD Best Practice Guidelines, Version 1.0.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2017-02-21 09:59:35 -0800.

repository.corpname: Department of Special Collections and University Archives

did.unittitle: Yamato Ichihashi papers

scopecontent.head: SCOPE AND CONTENT
scopecontent.p: The Yamato Ichihashi papers consist of a small amount of biographical material; reports, notes and surveys concerning foreign relations between Japan and the West, 1919-1928; uncorrected texts of the Washington Arms Limitation Conferences 1921-1922; reports and correspondence concerning the Institute of Pacific Relations, 1925; studies and surveys made by Ichihashi and others dealing with the Japanese immigration to the U.S.; articles and reviews by Ichihashi; class notes and syllabi of his Japanese History courses, and selected student papers. Boxes 5 through 8 contain correspondence, notes and some memoirs of the World War II relocation of Japanese and Japanese-Americans from the West Coast of the U.S. Boxes 9 through 12 contain 21 diaries covering the years 1943-1963 recording current international news events.

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHY
bioghist.p: Yamato Ichihashi, born in Japan, came to the United States and received his A.B. in Economics from Stanford in 1907, A.M. in 1908, and his Ph.D. from Harvard in 1914. He returned to Stanford in 1913 to become Professor of Japanese History and Government. His special interests included studies of Japanese in America and relations between Japan and the United States. He participated as observer and secretary for the Japanese Government during the Washington Arms limitation talks and conferences and the Institute of Pacific Relations. After Pearl Harbor, Dr. Ichihashi and his family were "relocated" with others of Japanese ancestry to places away from the immediate West Coast of the U.S. Following the end of the War, Ichihashi and his wife returned to Stanford.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation:
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Yamato Ichihashi Papers (SC0071). Dept. of Special Collections and University Archives, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

custodhist.head: Provenance:
custodhist.p: A gift of the Ichihashi estate to the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace in 1963; transferred to the Stanford University Archives in 1966. Additional gift of Woodrow Ichihashi, 1992.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights:
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with the repository. Literary rights reside with the creators of the documents or their heirs. To obtain permission to publish or reproduce, please contact the Public Services Librarian of the Dept. of Special Collections and University Archives.

did.unittitle: Professional
Biographical material; newspaper clippings concerning Japan's seizure of Manchukuo and Ichihashi's views on the possibility of war.
did.physdesc: Several documents and papers in Japanese.
